column2: Arrays can only store elements of the same data type.
column3: Linked lists have constant-time access to any element.

column2: Hash tables guarantee constant-time lookup for any key.
column3: Depth-first search always finds the shortest path in a weighted graph.
column4: Dijkstra's algorithm guarantees finding the shortest path in a graph with negative edge weights.

column2: Merge sort is a comparison-based sorting algorithm.
column3: Radix sort sorts numbers by processing individual digits.
column4: Binary trees have at most three children per node.

column2: Tries are primarily used for sorting integers.
column3: A red-black tree ensures balance by performing rotations.
column4: Breadth-first search explores as far as possible along each branch before backtracking.

column2: Bellman-Ford algorithm can handle graphs with negative edge weights.
column3: Huffman coding is a lossy compression technique.
column4: Topological sorting can be applied to graphs with cycles.
